content.description: The furthest left boulder problem in the West Side Boulders. Tight sit start from flat sloper both hands. Grab right pocket and long reach to jug sloper on the edge. Traverse to right on the corner and enjoy crux sloper section to the top. You won’t use any “Junk mail” jugs. I felt harder than V6 and easier than V7.

Start in underclings and move through the crimp to sidepulls and high feet till you reach the pipe hold than pull the lip, or tree hug it.

 Shares upper side pulls and top out with Friends.
content.location: Starts between Friends and Raid the Castle.

content.description: This is an extension of Lunar Eclipse, starting as a lowball traverse and then taking it to the top for an exciting finish. Start on the large horn just right of a tree, and traverse right ~10-15 feet staying low and then trending up and right to the finish hold of Lunar Eclipse.  Keep traversing right on some slopers to a good pocket and head for the top, just left of the tree.  This one builds on you, getting progressively harder and a lot more exciting...
content.protection: The crux is at the top and the landing is very uneven.  Pad 'er up!
content.location: Middle of the overhung highball bouldering area, going exactly from one small tree next to the wall to the other.

content.description: Start on a slopey ledge and smear up the wall to sidepulls.  Top out above the water grove.

Start low in a large two-hand slot and work through some crimpy pockets in a shallow crack up to where it widens into a pair of hand sized slots. Jam or lie back and reach high to finger lock in the parallel crack, and then go for the top out.
content.protection: Pads & spotters, preferably a few of each. The crux is towards the top...
content.location: Middle of the vertical section of the bouldering area, a few feet right of a tree growing near the base of the face.

content.description: Boulder up good edges and then use a large ear like hueco to get you to the top.
content.location: Right side bouldering area.  Just right of the last steep roof.

content.description:
Amazing line just left of the tree, left of psych.

 A couple dynamic moves to start then a big lockoff crux using an amazing edgy pinch just above the midway jug ledge.  I started with a scooped right hand sidepull/undercling at about chest height for a direct start and to avoid lesser quality rock and dirty holds to the left.  

 Regarding grade, I certainly gave it more than v7 effort, but my suspicion is that someone with more reach may walk it.  My wingspan is 5'8" ish and I really had to finger crawl for the crux lockoff.  Dialing that move took a bit more work than the long move on 'the drip.'  Whatever the grade, however, the holds are very cool and give rise to great moves.

 I know this has been cleaned and worked by others so if someone did it previously please chime in.

 edit:  i've plugged in a name.  for what it's worth, it comes from a yawpers song, mon nom, that was in my head around this time:

      Watch the fire consume it      And cry a savage verse.      Watch the better angels of nature      take a dive for the earth.
Hop up to a high, good ledge.  Mantle up, then climb to the lip using bad smears and sidepulls.

Start on a good ledge shoulder height.  Climb up on crimps to a seam before the roof.  Jump back to the large jug, then discover trickery to reach the top...

 Be sure to scout the top, as it is high and gets dirty easily.
content.protection: Crash pads, lots as the crux is the top and topout.

content.description: Sit start on a long ledge close to the ground.  This shares a start with Into the Sun.  Flip to an undercling and make a big throw up to a wide, deep slot.  Continue on slots to a long, sloping ledge just before the top out.
content.location: Located on the far left side of the Roof Boulder, at the end of the bouldering area.

content.description: Start on a large horn immediately to the right of a tree, just left of the start of Psych.  Traverse right on holds about head-height, before angling up and to the right.  Finish on a large hold just below the blank headwall
Start on a slopey ledge and climb up into the layback crack.  Preform a tricky mantle to gain the top.

An eliminate.  Climb the baguette without using the good stuff (the rail with the crimp pocket, slopers and edges) to the left for hands or feet.  You essentially go from the hand jam start straight to the little dogbone tufa crimp and lock that straight to the sloper pinch,  then dyno or campus still staying off that big sloer rail with your feet.

 This takes a great line (baguette) and swaps stars for v grade points, but I just wanted to see if i could pull on that crimp and get to the pinch directly... a test for my shoulder recovery... and a personal challenge, not a classic addition.
content.location: As for the baguette and contortionist

content.description: Starts left of mail slot on the two slots then finish same as mail slot. Added this variation due to the undercling start hold being snapped off of mail slot.

Sit start on a long ledge close to the ground.  This shares a start with Mail Slot.  Make a big move right to a small slot, then move up and right on more slots, before a big move to a slopey ledge just before the top.  Top out.
content.location: Located on the far left side of the Roof Boulder, at the end of the bouldering area.

content.description: Start from a stand on deep incut slots. Make some big moves where cutting feet may be easier.
content.location: Far left side of the crag, middle of the roof boulder starting on an obvious incut slot about chest height.

content.description: Start on double underclings and make move to an angeled slot.  Keep going up and right, on a bad slot and poor pinches to a gaston before the top.
content.protection: Crash pads.  The landing is flat, but the boulder is tall.

content.description: Start on a rough, protruding knob at head height.  Climb up on deep, slightly slopey ledges to a tricky topout that lacks feet.

Start on sidepulls on either side of a protruding block.  Climb up on slopey holds, then make a big sideways move right to a good crimp, and then top out on the slopey slab.  Avoid taking a direct approach by grabbing the good holds along the lower lip next to the crack.
content.protection: Crash Pads.  The boulder has a high crux.

content.description: Starts on Contortionist, moves left and links up with Grunt and Go and ends with Into the Sun
Start in the big waist-high pocket on a sloping ledge and head up and left through another big pocket.
content.location: On the far left end of the Bouldering Wall.  Starts on the right side of the last big overhanging bulge before the end of the wall.

content.description:
Start standing left of savage verse 10ft-ish.  I started direct, avoiding the dirty and more friable stone to the right.  work through slopers and edges to gain a horizontal ledge system at mid height.  For the last pull to the ledge use the fattest part of the hold at the lip.  The thinner section may snap off.  Balance off the rail to a difficult right hand sloping hold and do a big and somewhat insecure lock off to a thin horizontal crimp slot.  Without a good matching option, there's another long reach to the lip rewarded by an easy mantle.

 Like with the neighbors, the upper rock on this is really good.  It would get all the stars if the start was more singular and the lower lip holds were not suspect.

 Re: grade: Harder and less secure lockoff than savage verse with easier set up moves.  Could be harder than 7, but my radar is way off.  The last established 7 i did was covert direct in the red. In comparison, this was two full grades harder for me but FAs always feel harder, so...?
content.protection: Rock ledge in the landing. Pad it up.

content.description:
Start standing with the ledge straight under the little chossy bat cave feature. Climb up to the jugs at the cave, lock off to the pinchy sloping left hand sidepull and fight the barndoor to stab right hand to a juggy scoop/hueco. Easy finish from here.

 Im short and used a kneebar for the first big reach.

 Looks like it should be super easy but it gave me fits.  Getting into and maintaining the crux left pinch while finding the right balance to stab to the good right hold was powerful and techy. .. took more effort than "psych" but not saying its harder.  Could be easier with different positioning. You decide.
content.protection: Pad er up.  Ledge in the landing.

content.description:
Big move to the ledge under the roof, and then get into the business in the crack above.  Some jams are sinker, some not so much.

 What is a shoe in the bush worth exactly?!  In the hand?
content.protection: Pads... Preferably a few!  Try not to fall up top. Crux comes about halfway between the roof and the topout.
content.location: Far left end of the crag, past the slabby wall and before the really steep stuff.  Obvious hand crack just left of a tree next to the trail.

content.description: Start with your hands in a slot deep under the roof with your feet on a ramp.  This is the same start as Contortionist.  Climb towards a round pinch ledge in the middle of the roof, possibly using holds on Contortionist, then go big to the ledge.  Perform a high heelhook to get to the lip and mantle over at the corner of the boulder.

An outstanding collection of 20+ boulder problems, with some short and steep, some slabby and techy, and some legit puckerfest highballs. Many stay dry more or less year round, and others will be drenched from November to May. Several lines here would be classics in any area, let alone central OH. Some have large flat landings, but others will need all the pads you can muster to make 'em safe.

 Please do not hang out up top or go exploring above the main cliff line. It is private property and we need to keep a low profile. The owner has been hands off so far. Let's try to ensure things stay that way please.
